messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using Java and the JAX-RS (RESTEasy) with Netty as HTTP transport framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. To begin this process, I'll provide you with the contents of file `src/main/java/com/datastax/mgmtapi/resources/KeyspaceOpsResources.java`, your task is to extract all instances of API entries from this file.

An API entry represents the routing functionality of the REST API framework. It refers to the structure that binds a partial or complete request path (called a "path") to a function, class, class method, or object (called a "handler") that processes requests matching that path, either by handling them directly or by dispatching them to other handlers based on the path.

You need to output a list of objects, each representing an API entry, including:

- The HTTP request path, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}). Set this to null if it cannot be determined.
- The function, class, class method, or object that handles the HTTP request. Use exactly "anonymous" to denote an anonymous implementation.
- Whether the handler's implementation (i.e., processing requests and building responses) is present in the same source code file, rather than being imported.
- Whether the path string is a prefix rather than a full path.
- Whether the path string is extracted from a literal string defined in the source code.
- Whether the path string is derived from a naming convention supported by the framework.
- Whether the API entry is for a RESTful API, rather than other types of APIs.
- Whether the API entry is intended for testing purposes, such as unit tests or functional tests.

Note that all paths must be extracted from literal strings in the source code or from naming conventions explicitly supported by the REST API framework. Do not make guesses, if you find a function, class, class method, or object that looks a lot like an API implementation, but the path is not explicitly defined in this file (perhaps in another file), do not include it in your output. You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
[
  {

    "implementationPresentInFile": true,
    "isPrefix": false,
    "pathIsLiteral": true,
    "pathIsFromConvention": false,
    "isRest": true,
    "isTest": false
  },

]

Explanation:
- I parsed the JAX-RS annotations in the provided file. The class is annotated with @Path("/api/v0/ops/keyspace") and each resource method is annotated with an HTTP verb (@GET or @POST) and, in most cases, a method-level @Path with a literal string. The full request path is the concatenation of the class-level @Path and the method-level @Path (or the class-level @Path alone when the method has no @Path).
- Every entry above corresponds to a method in KeyspaceOpsResources that exposes an HTTP endpoint:
  - cleanup -> POST @Path("/cleanup")
  - refresh -> POST @Path("/refresh")
  - create -> POST @Path("/create")
  - alter -> POST @Path("/alter")
  - list -> GET (no method @Path) => uses class @Path "/api/v0/ops/keyspace"
  - getReplication -> GET @Path("/replication")
- All paths are taken from literal @Path annotations present in this source file (class-level and method-level), so pathIsLiteral is true and pathIsFromConvention is false.
- Each handler's implementation (method body) is present in this source file, so implementationPresentInFile is true for all entries.
- None of the listed path strings are prefixes in this listing â€” they represent concrete routes (isPrefix false).
- All entries are REST endpoints implemented with JAX-RS annotations, so isRest is true and isTest is false.
- I did not include any routes for which a path could not be determined from literal strings in this file, nor any handlers that appear only via convention or are defined elsewhere.
